awd_titl_txt: Wave-Wave Interactions and Upper Atmosphere Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
Large-scale vertically-propagating waves such as planetary waves (PW) and tidal waves (TW) represent the primary means by which energy from lower atmosphere meteorological activity is transmitted into the upper atmosphere region. The coupling interaction between these waves is believed to be a source of strong variability that is transmitted into the upper atmosphere and ionosphere as secondary wave structures that could potentially affect navigation, communications and radar tracking systems. Understanding the origins of such variability in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) region is one of the major challenges faced in space physics. This award would focus on studying these large-scale wave interactions and the secondary waves they produce by using a year-long dataset generated by the use of a NCAR general circulation model (TIME-GCM), coupled to the use of the Global Scale Wave Model (GSWM) that would provide simulations of the lower atmosphere inputs into the upper atmosphere model. The broader impacts of the research effort will be realized in several different ways: (a) engagement with a diverse population of students through partnership with the Broadening Opportunity through Leadership and Diversity (BOLD) Center; (b) engaging an undergraduate student in the research through the Discovery Learning Apprentice (DLA) Program; (c) leveraging the above connections to teach graduate students how to mentor. 

For individual cases where non-linear interactions are seen, a non-linear version of the GSWM model will be employed to perform numerical experiments, investigating factors such as how the phases of the two primary waves impact the generation of the secondary waves. The primary objectives of the work are as follows:  1) to delineate and understand the basic mechanisms underlying the interactions between PWs and tides propagating up from the lower atmosphere, 2) to quantify the variability imposed on the global atmosphere-ionosphere system by these interactions, and 3) to assess the implications for ground-based and space-based observing systems.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project are to delineate and understand the interactions between atmospheric waves and the background atmosphere through which they propagate, interactions between and among the waves themselves, and the roles that these waves play in imposing variability on the electrically-charged part of the atmosphere (i.e., the "ionosphere"). The wave types include solar thermal tides; quasi-2, -6 and -10-day(d) planetary waves (PWs; Q2DWs, Q6DWs, Q10DWs), and ultra-fast Kelvin waves. The tides arise from the cyclic heating arising from absorption of solar radiation in the atmosphere below about 65 km, and by the heat of condensation released when water droplets form in convective clouds. The periodicity of solar tides are thus fractions of a solar day, i.e., 24h, 12h, 8h, etc. The PWs are near-resonant oscillations of the atmosphere, and arise naturally in response to meteorological variability across a range of periods. A Kelvin wave is a type of wave that is equatorially-trapped, is excited by tropical convective systems, with wave periods between about 2d and 20d. Ultra-fast Kelvin waves (UFKWs) are those Kelvin waves with periods less than about 5d that can survive the trip to the highest regions of the atmosphere. Any two of the above-described waves can interact with each other to produce two secondary waves (SWs), each with periods and spatial structures different than the primary interacting waves. Moreover, each of the above waves can become "distorted" by the large-scale wind field through which they propagate, and dissipation of waves can dump momentum into the background atmosphere to modify the very flow through which they propagate.

The above goals are achieved in part through analysis of a g 3-dimensional time-dependent full-physics simulation of the atmosphere and ionosphere extending from 30 km to 500 km altitude, consisting of the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) TIMEGCM (Thermosphere Ionosphere Mesosphere Electrodynamics General Circulation Model) forced at its ~30-km lower boundary by 3-hourly global reanalysis data from MERRA (Modern-Era Retrospective Analysis for Research and Applications) for the full year of 2009. This type of approach is necessary due to the paucity of global measurements of the upper regions of the atmosphere. These analyses are supplemented by observational analyses that augment, guide and validate the model analyses, and numerical experiments with a simpler numerical model (the Global-Scale Wave Model, GSWM) that isolate and elucidate how nonlinear interactions between two primary waves spawn secondary waves (SWs).

Some of the accomplishments of this project are as follows. Concerning the Q6DW, it was demonstrated through analyses of satellite-based (SB) data that signatures of the SW that arise from Q6DW-tide interactions actually exist in the atmosphere. Moreover, a new two-stage nonlinear tidal interaction scheme was formulated and quantified through modeling, using the Q6DW as an example, that demonstrates how a PW-modulated tidal spectrum can feed back to modify the original modulating PW. Using ground-based (GB) observations, the existence of SWs arising from interactions of the semidiurnal tide with the Q2DW and Q10DW, and the "quenching" of high-order (4-, 4.75- and 6-h period) tides due to interactions with the background wind field after onset of a stratosphere sudden warming event were also demonstrated. Through modeling, the physical processes by which dissipation of vertically propagating tides act to alter the mean dynamical state of the thermosphere were elucidated at a new level. The above accomplishments are reported in 7 journal publications. 

A series of 5 additional papers were written that elucidated new facets of UFKWs: the SWs that arise from UFKW-tide interactions; the effects of mean winds and dissipation on the propagation of UFKWs and the SWs; the ionospheric variability that arises from UFKWs, and interactions between UFKWs and the ionosphere itself; and how UFKW-ionosphere interactions are manifested in variations in Earth's magnetic field observed at the surface. Two additional review papers were published by the PI, one entitled "Wave Coupling and Nonlinear Interactions in the Atmospheres of Earth and Mars", and the other entitled "Atmosphere-Ionosphere (A-I) Coupling by Solar and Lunar Tides".

The waves discussed above are relevant to our 21st-century society since they represent a large portion of the "planetary-scale" wave spectrum that is excited in lower atmosphere regions and that propagate into the ionosphere-thermosphere (IT) system (100-500 km altitude). It is in the IT where they can impose variability that can degrade communications, tracking and navigation systems, and can hinder accurate satellite and orbital debris trajectory predictions. These waves essentially transmit the meteorological variability ("weather") of lower atmosphere regions to that of the IT and thus drive an element of near-Earth "space weather" that increasingly requires a higher level of predictability in order to protect civilian and military assets in space. The basic research performed under this NSF-funded research provides some of the basic scientific understanding needed in order to develop such a predictive capability.
